cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: What is another name for front-end header boards?
questions.answerB: Cargo stoppers
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: While driving, if it is discovered a vehicle's ABS is not working, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Downshift.
questions.answerD: Use their parking brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are still intact. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A child on the side of the road
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when you are near people who are not paying attention to the road. Be wary of drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers, children near the road, and road workers.

questions.question: If one air system in a dual air brake system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully.
questions.answerC: There will be no noticeable affect.
questions.answerD: Lights on the outside of the tractor will flash.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: Loading cargo:
questions.answerA: Must be done by the driver.
questions.answerB: Can be done by a second person who is responsible for the safety of the cargo.
questions.answerC: Can be done by a second person, but the driver is responsible for the safety of the cargo.
questions.answerD: Must be done by a person from the shipping company.
questions.explanation: Regardless of who has loaded cargo onto a vehicle, the driver is responsible for the safety of the cargo.

questions.question: If you need to travel down a hill, you should switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed.
questions.answerD: Near the bottom of the hill.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Forcing an automatic transmission into a lower gear at a high speed could damage the transmission and also lead to a loss of ability to engine brake. Drive at a speed that will allow you to control your vehicle without overusing your brakes. When determining a safe speed to drive, you should take into account the steepness of the grade, the length of the grade, the weight of your vehicle, road conditions, and weather conditions.

questions.question: A vehicle should be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Spare electrical fuses.
questions.answerC: Warning devices for parked vehicles, such as flares.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicles should always carry the proper emergency equipment. Be sure your vehicle is equipped with at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses, unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers; and warning devices for parked vehicles, such as warning triangles, fuses, or liquid burning flares.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: 250 feet
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: If you see lights ahead while driving in fog:
questions.answerA: You can assume the lights are on the road.
questions.answerB: It may be a reflection.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.answerD: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.answerB: 100 psi.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: Driving too fast:
questions.answerA: Is a major cause of fatal crashes.
questions.answerB: Can be a good way to get to your destination quickly.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the roadway is dry.
questions.explanation: Driving at excessive speeds is a major cause of fatal crashes. Never drive above the posted maximum speed limit and adjust your speed to fit conditions.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely travel under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have space for your vehicle to safely fit underneath an overhead object, slow down and seek an alternate route if possible.

questions.question: If unsure if a road is becoming icy, a driver can:
questions.answerB: Open the window and check the front of the mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Try to look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy, you can check for ice on your vehicle by opening the window and feeling the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment should be:
questions.answerB: Checked before every trip.
questions.answerC: Checked, but only if the driver plans to use the mirrors.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of your mirrors should be checked prior to the start of all trips. Adjust your mirrors as needed.

questions.question: What is the minimum permitted size of a placard?
questions.answerB: Seven square inches
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials must be diamond-shaped and a size of at least 10 ¾ square inches.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: React to the driver's gestures.
questions.answerC: Challenge the driver to a road race.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is get out of their way, if possible. Do not provoke the driver by challenging them or making eye contact, and do not let yourself be provoked by rude gestures they might make.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay off the brakes.
questions.answerD: Wave your arms at other drivers.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes after a tire failure could cause you to lose control of your vehicle. Unless you're about to hit something, stay off of the brake until the vehicle has slowed sufficiently.

questions.question: Slippery roadways usually:
questions.answerA: Make it more difficult to stop a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Make it easier to stop a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to drive a vehicle.
questions.answerD: Can be avoided by driving at night.
questions.explanation: It takes a longer distance to stop a vehicle on a slippery road than it does on a dry road. Use caution when driving under conditions that could cause a road surface to become slippery.

questions.question: If cargo on a flatbed trailer is 40 feet long, it must be secured by a minimum of:
questions.answerB: Two tie-downs.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: When checking your mirrors:
questions.answerA: Do not use the passenger side mirror.
questions.answerB: Do not use the driver's side mirror.
questions.answerD: Look in each mirror for long stretches of time.
questions.explanation: To travel safely, it is essential that you know what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Check all mirrors frequently while driving.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerB: Inappropriately dressed.
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: 100 yards
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: If loading cargo that will not entirely fill up a trailer, the cargo should be placed:
questions.answerA: At the front of the trailer.
questions.answerB: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.answerC: In the middle of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Cargo must be properly balanced so that there is neither too little nor too much weight on the front or rear axles. Improperly balanced cargo can damage a vehicle and affect the handling of a vehicle.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.answerB: Black ice
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a truck's cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: Why are roads especially slippery right after it begins to rain?
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Roads are naturally slippery.
questions.answerC: Gravel often gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Tires are not usually designed to drive in rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, roads are often at their most slippery when the rain first begins to fall. Fresh rainwater mixes with oil and grease on the road to form a slick film. As the rain continues, this mixture will eventually wash away.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.answerB: Landing gear.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: When starting the engine as part of the pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Rev the engine.
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: When about to drive a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up to ensure the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait for air pressure to build in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the engine starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the compressor to build up pressure to at least 100 psi in both systems.

questions.question: In cold weather, an alcohol evaporator should be checked and filled:
questions.answerB: Every day.
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass slower vehicles.
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the railroad crossing.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Maintain full-capacity air pressure in the braking systems even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking systems when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build enough air pressure to brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Do not need time to build air pressure before a trip.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must allow the air compressor time to build up at least 100 psi of air pressure in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: A vehicle must be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Spare electrical fuses.
questions.answerC: Warning devices for a parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: The Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The route of travel.
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include the following information about distance traveled: trip start and end dates; trip origin and destination points; route(s) of travel; beginning and ending odometer or hubometer readings; total distance traveled; in-jurisdiction distance; and power unit number or vehicle identification number.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of the engine.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.answerD: Should be done on surfaces with poor traction.
questions.explanation: Accelerate smoothly and gradually. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Which of the following can help you determine when to upshift?
questions.answerB: Engine speed
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: What is a concern immediately after it begins raining?
questions.answerA: The water will mix with grease and oil on the road, making the roadway slippery.
questions.answerB: A driver may forget where the windshield wiper lever is located.
questions.answerD: People will be using their windshield wipers needlessly.
questions.explanation: Under wet conditions, roads are often most slippery when it first begins to rain. This is because the water mixes with oil and grease on the road that has not yet begun to wash away.

questions.question: What is black ice?
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet.

questions.question: If someone pulls out in front of you and you cannot stop to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Just hit the other vehicle since it will be the other driver's fault.
questions.answerB: Swerve to avoid the other car.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle pulls out in front of you, it is appropriate to brake as long as there is room for your vehicle to stop while you are using the appropriate braking technique. However, if you do not have room to stop, swerving may be a safer response.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stay as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the flames.
questions.answerD: Aim the fire extinguisher at the ground about two feet away from the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stay as far away from the flames as possible and aim at the base of the fire.

questions.question: A CMV should:
questions.answerA: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless the vehicle will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerD: Have a fire extinguisher and other emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: When driving with covered cargo, a cover that flaps:
questions.answerB: Allows air to keep the cargo cool.
questions.explanation: Cargo covers should not flap in the wind. They could tear loose, not only uncovering the cargo but also blocking the views of drivers.

questions.question: What do headers do?
questions.answerA: Protect the driver during a crash
questions.answerB: Provide a place for storage
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards protect the driver from the forward motion of their cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.answerB: Brakes overheat.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.answerB: Contain rags.
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the roadway:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Is usually empty.
questions.answerC: May contain a heavy object that could damage your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided by driving off the roadway.
questions.explanation: Any foreign object on the road is potentially dangerous. For example, something seemingly harmless, such as a cardboard box or paper sack, could contain a hard or heavy object that could do serious damage to a vehicle.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull off the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: What kind of force must emergency brakes use?
questions.answerB: Mechanical
questions.explanation: Because air pressure can eventually leak away, the emergency brakes in an air brake system must be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered a look?
questions.answerA: Walking to the back of a vehicle to check its position
questions.answerB: Using side mirrors to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerC: Looking out of the driver's side window to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerD: A driver glancing over their shoulder to check blind spots
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: In an emergency, if you must leave the roadway to drive on the shoulder, you should:
questions.answerB: Steer so all wheels are on the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stop safely before returning to the road, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on the shoulder until the next exit.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to drive onto the shoulder of a road, you should try to keep one set of wheels on the pavement to maintain better control of your vehicle. If possible, stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has come to a complete stop, then pull back onto the road when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: 250 feet
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, what is the best method for checking your lights?
questions.answerA: Parking near a mirror to look for a reflection
questions.answerB: Activating the lights, then exiting the vehicle to check
questions.answerC: Looking on the instrument panel to see if any warning lights are illuminated
questions.answerD: Driving in traffic and waiting for other drivers to let you know your lights are out
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should activate your lights, then get out of the vehicle to look at them.

questions.question: What is a way to warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down?
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate the brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get other drivers’ attention.
questions.answerD: Turn all lights on and off several times.
questions.explanation: To alert drivers behind you that you plan to slow down, tap your brake pedal lightly a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: Tires of mismatched sizes:
questions.answerA: May be used on a tractor.
questions.answerB: May be used on a trailer.
questions.answerC: Should be used in adverse weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should not be used on a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Having tires of mismatched sizes on a vehicle is a problem that should be fixed if discovered during a vehicle inspection.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.answerB: 100 psi.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely travel under a bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have space for your vehicle to safely fit underneath an overhead object, slow down and seek an alternate route if possible.

questions.question: When a tire goes flat, you may hear a loud bang. The truck will be affected:
questions.answerB: After a short delay.
questions.answerC: Only if the damaged tire is near the front of the truck.
questions.answerD: Only if the truck is hauling a load.
questions.explanation: There may be a delay of a few seconds between the sound of a tire failing and the time that the vehicle is affected by the tire failure. Because of the short delay, a driver may initially believe that the sound came from another vehicle.

questions.question: To stop a vehicle using air brakes:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be lifted.
questions.answerC: The brake knob should be pulled out.
questions.answerD: The brake knob should be pushed in.
questions.explanation: To stop normally in a vehicle with air brakes, press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When driving through work zones, you should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: Where must placards be placed?
questions.answerA: Only on the front of a vehicle
questions.answerB: On the front, back and both sides of a vehicle
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of a vehicle
questions.answerD: Only on the passenger's side of the vehicle
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials that require placarding, there must be identical placards placed on the front, rear, and both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: Retreaded tires:
questions.answerA: May be used on any part of a bus.
questions.answerB: May be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: May be used on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerD: May never be used on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited from use on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: What does driving intrastate mean?
questions.answerB: Traveling from one state to another state
questions.explanation: Intrastate commerce is defined as when you drive a CMV only within a single state, and the cargo you are carrying is not part of a trip that began or will end outside of the state.

questions.question: An applicant will be denied a hazardous materials endorsement if they:
questions.answerB: Are wanted for a misdemeanor.
questions.explanation: Your application for a hazardous materials endorsement can be denied, or your existing endorsement canceled, if you do not have legal permanent status in the United States; you renounce U.S. citizenship; you are wanted for, under indictment for, or convicted of certain felonies; you are judged mentally incompetent or are involuntarily committed to a mental institution; or you are deemed by the Transportation Security Administration to pose a security threat.

questions.question: If driving in a foggy area, you should not:
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: It is safest not to drive in foggy areas. However, if you must drive through fog, you should slow down, use your low beam headlights and fog lights, and turn on your four-way flashers.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a rule for using turn signals?
questions.answerB: Signal continuously.
questions.answerC: Cancel your signal once your turn or lane change is complete.
questions.answerD: Don’t signal unless another vehicle is close.
questions.explanation: Always signal before a turn or lane change. Begin signaling well in advance of the movement and keep the signal on continuously during the turn. If it is not self-canceling, make sure to turn your signal off after your turn or lane change is complete.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.answerB: 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: When checking your vehicle's lights before driving:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be running and in gear.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The check can be done from inside the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The check can be done by looking at a reflection from a shiny surface.
questions.explanation: To check your vehicle's lights before a trip, you should set the parking brake, turn off the engine, remove the key from the ignition, and take the key with you. Turn on your low beam headlights and four-way flashers. Get out of the vehicle to make sure the lights are working properly.

questions.question: Be sure you are always driving so your vehicle can stop:
questions.answerA: Within 10 feet of your current position.
questions.answerB: Within 1,000 feet of your current position.
questions.answerC: Within your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be sure that you are driving in a manner that will allow your vehicle to come to a complete stop, if necessary, within the area of the road ahead that you are able to see.

questions.question: When traveling with cargo, you must make sure the cargo is secure:
questions.answerB: Every 150 miles or three hours of driving.
questions.answerC: Only after traveling up a hill.
questions.answerD: Only after coming to a hard stop.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: If coolant has to be added to a system without a recovery tank, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the vehicle running while adding coolant.
questions.answerB: Open the radiator cap quickly.
questions.answerC: Not use gloves to touch the radiator cap.
questions.answerD: Wait for the engine to cool before adding coolant.
questions.explanation: Before adding coolant to a system without a recovery or overflow tank, you must turn the engine off and wait until it cools. Use gloves or a thick cloth to protect your hands. To release the pressure seal, turn the radiator cap slowly to the first stop.

questions.question: While driving, if it is discovered a vehicle's ABS is not working, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Downshift.
questions.answerD: Use their parking brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are still intact. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: A cargo of hanging meat:
questions.answerA: Is stable due to the placement of the load.
questions.answerB: Can be problematic because animals may be attracted to the scent of the meat.
questions.answerC: Is unstable due to its high center of gravity.
questions.answerD: Is discouraged during the summer months.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: Fatigue:
questions.answerB: Can impair driving.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous and increases the risk of a crash. Take precautions before a trip to prevent driving while fatigued.

questions.question: In general, if you are convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerA: The convicting officer will alert your employer.
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected because the violation is on your personal license.
questions.answerC: You should tell your employer within six months.
questions.answerD: You must tell your employer within 30 days.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: What happens if brakes become too hot?
questions.answerB: They will harden.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick in to cool the brakes
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they may overheat and stop working. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.answerB: Tight.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: The safety valve located on the first tank opens:
questions.answerB: If there is too little pressure.
questions.answerC: If there is too much pressure.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the first tank that receives compressed air has a safety valve that releases air if the pressure gets too high. It is usually set to open at 150 psi. If the valve must open, there is a fault in the system that should be repaired by a mechanic.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.answerB: Landing gear.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: What is another name for front end header boards?
questions.answerB: Cargo stoppers
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is not another name for convex mirrors?
questions.answerB: Spot mirrors
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are also known as "fisheye", "spot", or "bug-eye" mirrors.

questions.question: If driving a vehicle with a manual transmission, you can prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when starting from a stop by:
questions.answerA: Partly engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Placing the vehicle in reverse before moving forward.
questions.answerC: Fully engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Placing the vehicle in neutral before moving forward.
questions.explanation: To prevent rolling backward when starting from a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake. Apply the parking brake whenever necessary to prevent your vehicle from rolling back.

questions.question: When the spring brakes are activated in a vehicle with air brakes, you should never:
questions.answerB: Turn the vehicle off.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, never push the brake pedal down when the spring brakes are activated. The combined force of the springs and the pressure of the air brakes could damage the brakes.

questions.question: Escape ramps are:
questions.answerA: Ramps to exit the interstate quickly.
questions.answerB: Ramps connecting four-lane highways and two-lane highways.
questions.answerC: Ramps that can be used by stop runaway vehicles on steep downhills.
questions.answerD: Ramps that cannot be used by automobiles.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are constructed in areas with steep downgrades to allow a means of safely stopping runaway vehicles. They consist of a long bed of loose, soft material, and sometimes an uphill slope.

questions.question: Before beginning downhill, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your vehicle out of gear.
questions.answerD: Rely only on braking to reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill. Relying too heavily on the brakes may cause them to overheat and fade, becoming less effective.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, the vehicle:
questions.answerB: Should be parked downhill.
questions.answerD: May have to be left running.
questions.explanation: For some vehicles, you may need to leave the engine running to be able to check its automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: When a construction worker is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerD: Wait to proceed until the construction is complete.
questions.explanation: In construction zones, do not exceed the posted safe sped limit. Slow down even more when workers are near the roadway.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation, you must inform your employer ____ of the violation.
questions.answerB: Within a week
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: Why are roads particularly slippery right after it begins to rain?
questions.answerA: Water mixes with grease and oil on the road.
questions.answerB: Roads are naturally slippery.
questions.answerC: Gravel gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Some tires are not designed for rain.
questions.explanation: Roads are often at their most slippery when rain is just beginning to fall. This is because water mixes with oil and grease on the road to create a slick surface. As rain continues, the oil and grease will wash away.

questions.question: In an engine compartment, loose belts will:
questions.answerA: Not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, causing the engine to overheat.
questions.answerB: Make the engine run more efficiently.
questions.answerC: Make the fan run too much, causing the engine to run too coolly.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check the tightness of the belts in your engine compartment. Loose belts will not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, which can lead the engine overheating.

questions.question: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure in your brakes, you should downshift, pump the brakes, and use the parking brake. Seek an escape route, such as an escape ramp, open field, or side street.

questions.question: To prevent your tires and engine from overheating while you are driving in especially hot weather, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive, the hotter your engine and tires will become. When it is very hot, you can help prevent this overheating by decreasing your speed.

questions.question: An underloaded front axle:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged as front axles are usually less strong than other axles.
questions.answerC: Is discouraged as it can cause steering problems.
questions.answerD: Is discouraged as it can improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: Underloading a front axle may make it impossible to safely steer your vehicle. Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of a potentially drunk driver?
questions.answerA: They are staying in their traffic lane.
questions.answerB: They are driving a consistent speed.
questions.answerC: They are stopping without a reason.
questions.answerD: They have alcohol-related bumper stickers on their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Warning signs that a driver may be impaired include that they are having trouble staying in their lane, they are having trouble maintaining an appropriate driving speed, or they are stopping without a clear reason.

questions.question: While driving:
questions.answerA: A driver does not need to inform others of their intentions.
questions.answerB: A driver should only use turn signals if a vehicle is next to them.
questions.answerC: A driver should not use a turn signal if their lane change will be obvious.
questions.answerD: A driver should always use turn signals to inform others of their intentions.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a driver always uses proper signals to make their intentions known to others on the road.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer:
questions.answerA: You should not back up in a straight line.
questions.answerB: You should not correct drift until you are very far off course.
questions.answerC: You should pull up to reposition the vehicle as needed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, you should pull up to reposition your vehicle as needed.

questions.question: Driving too fast:
questions.answerA: Is a major cause of fatal crashes.
questions.answerB: Can be a good way to get to your destination quickly.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the roadway is dry.
questions.explanation: Driving at excessive speeds is a major cause of fatal crashes. Never drive above the posted maximum speed limit and adjust your speed to fit conditions.

questions.question: Suspension system defects may include all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Missing or broken leaves.
questions.explanation: Defects to check for when inspecting your vehicle's suspension system include cracked or broken spring hangers; missing or broken leaves in a leaf spring; and leaking shock absorbers. If you spot any of these issues, be sure to have them repaired.

questions.question: Where is the safety relief valve usually located?
questions.answerB: Near the front brake
questions.explanation: An air brake system's safety relief valve is located in the tank that is first to receive air from the compressor.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.answerB: Glued down.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers or trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: Move over laws require:
questions.answerA: Trucks to use the left lane.
questions.answerB: All vehicles to vacate the lane closest to an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing.
questions.answerC: All vehicles to use the left lane.
questions.answerD: All vehicles to move to the left lane if a flatbed trailer is in the right lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with its lights on is stopped on the side of the road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: If you’re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both mirrors, as that can cause too much distraction.
questions.answerC: Wait for someone else to back up in the area so you see how they do it.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle. Especially if you are unfamiliar with the area, you should get out of your vehicle and familiarize yourself with your path of travel before beginning to back up.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Air compressor governor
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: It is important to take turns and curves at a safe speed. You should always downshift before entering a curve.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.answerD: Clean the air in the passenger compartment.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes. Manually operated drains should be used daily.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: To make driving at night easier, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your interior light turned on.
questions.answerB: Adjust the instrument panel lights as dimly as you can while still being able to read the gauges.
questions.answerC: Not take a nap before driving.
questions.answerD: Use only your low beam headlights.
questions.explanation: If the interior of your cab is too bright when you are driving at night, you may have difficulty seeing things outside. Keep the interior light off and adjust your instrument lights to the lowest possible level that still allows you to easily read the gauges.

questions.question: Hanging meat as a cargo:
questions.answerB: Creates an unstable load.
questions.answerD: Creates a low center of gravity.
questions.explanation: Hanging meat can be an unstable load in a vehicle. The truck may become top-heavy and steering may be inhibited by the swinging meat. Drivers carrying such loads should use particular caution when traveling around sharp curves, such as highway entrance and exit ramps.

questions.question: Leaking shock absorbers:
questions.answerB: Indicate a potentially dangerous defect.
questions.answerC: Will prevent the turn signals from working.
questions.answerD: Pose no threat if the vehicle is only driven on highways.
questions.explanation: The suspension system keeps a vehicle's axles in place. Damaged suspension parts, such as leaking shock absorbers, may be potentially dangerous defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: Overloading cargo can have negative effects on all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.explanation: Overloading a vehicle can have negative effects on its steering, braking, and speed control. Be aware of how your vehicle handles differently when carrying additional weight.

questions.question: When turning quickly to avoid an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply your brakes as you steer.
questions.answerB: Give yourself extra clearance by turning more than needed to miss the object.
questions.answerC: Turn just enough to miss the object and avoid turning more.
questions.answerD: Steer and accelerate at the same time.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid an object, turn only as much as is necessary to clear it. Do not apply the brakes while turning.

questions.question: Escape ramps are:
questions.answerA: Ramps to exit the interstate quickly.
questions.answerB: Ramps connecting four-lane highways and two-lane highways.
questions.answerC: Ramps that can be used by stop runaway vehicles on steep downhills.
questions.answerD: Ramps that cannot be used by automobiles.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are constructed in areas with steep downgrades to allow a means of safely stopping runaway vehicles. They consist of a long bed of loose, soft material, and sometimes an uphill slope.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.answerB: A loud horn.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.answerB: The parking brake system
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer attached to the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.answerD: The vehicle is on a slight decline.
questions.explanation: If a trailer is attached to a tractor, the adjustment of the vehicle's mirrors can only be checked accurately if the trailer is straight.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: Tires of mismatched sizes:
questions.answerA: Can be used only on a front axle.
questions.answerB: Can be used only on a trailer's axles.
questions.explanation: Tires on the same vehicle should all be equally sized. Ensure your tires are not mismatched when inspecting your vehicle.

questions.question: Without securing a load on a flatbed trailer, cargo may:
questions.answerB: Shift or fall off of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Create a glare, blinding other motorists.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be secured to prevent it from shifting or falling in transit.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts are loose.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: How many seconds of following distance per every 10 feet of vehicle should you maintain when traveling more slowly than 40 mph?
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.explanation: When traveling at speeds below 40 mph, you should maintain at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. At higher speeds, add an additional second.

questions.question: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: Applicants will not have to identify the ABS.
questions.answerB: Windshield wipers are not to be addressed.
questions.answerC: Shock absorbers only need to be checked on one axle.
questions.answerD: The steering box should be checked for leaks.
questions.explanation: During the external inspection portion of the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you must verify that the steering box is securely mounted and not leaking.

questions.question: Why do drivers have to inspect their vehicles?
questions.answerA: It is usually a company policy.
questions.answerB: It is usually a local ordinance.
questions.answerC: It is a federal and state law.
questions.answerD: It adds to the amount of time for which they will be paid.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles before driving to ensure that they are safe to operate.

questions.question: When inspecting a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should be sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at the proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: The hoses do not contain any fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. Be sure to check for and repair leaks before operating the vehicle.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in work zones?
questions.answerB: Careless behavior by construction workers
questions.explanation: Speeding traffic is the main cause of death and injury in work zones. Drive with special caution when traveling near road workers.

questions.question: Laws about securing loads and regulating CMV weights may vary from state to state. During interstate travel:
questions.answerA: The law of the state in which the trip originated takes precedence.
questions.answerB: The law of the state the vehicle is in takes precedence.
questions.answerC: The driver should request federal regulations to override conflicting state laws.
questions.answerD: The driver can choose which state’s laws to follow.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicle weight, securement of cargo, covering of loads, and where large vehicles can be driven are all regulated by federal, state, and local laws. These vary from place to place, so you must be aware of the rules that apply where you will be driving. State laws in the state in which you are driving take precedence.

questions.question: What does ABS do?
questions.answerB: Prevent the air compressor from overheating
questions.answerC: Prevent the front brakes from being used on ice
questions.answerD: Prevent the brakes from being used if downshifting would be more effective
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheels from locking up during hard applications of the brakes, especially on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.answerB: Axle.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you would inspect and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load in a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the CDL vehicle inspection test, you must be able to inspect your vehicle and explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.answerB: Engine
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a vehicle inspection report?
questions.answerA: It tells the motor carrier about problems that may need to be fixed.
questions.answerB: It ensures that the vehicle is inspected regularly.
questions.answerC: It keeps drivers accountable for inspecting their vehicles.
questions.answerD: It provides a plan for the next five trips.
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report allows a driver to inform the motor carrier of issues that could affect the safe operation of a vehicle. If required, the driver should fill out a vehicle inspection report after every day of driving. They should make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: What may happen if the exhaust system is not working properly?
questions.answerA: Poisonous fumes may enter the cab.
questions.answerB: Poisonous fumes may exit the rear of the muffler system.
questions.answerD: It may cause problems if the trailer is fully loaded.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can allow poisonous fumes to enter a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to regularly check your exhaust system for defects.

questions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerB: Use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you should slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: To stop in a vehicle that uses air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Engage the brake lever.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle with air brakes, push the brake pedal down. The harder the pedal is pressed, the more air pressure is released.

questions.question: If your tractor is equipped with ABS but your trailer is not, the ABS:
questions.answerB: Will still improve your steering control.
questions.answerD: Will allow others to see when you brake.
questions.explanation: In a tractor-trailer combination, if the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the ABS will still improve the driver's steering control. The driver should keep an eye on the trailer and let up on the brakes if the trailer begins to swing out.

questions.question: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is equipped on a trailer but not on a tractor:
questions.answerA: The truck should not be driven because ABS needs to be on both the tractor and trailer.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: The tractor should not be used and a new tractor with ABS should be located.
questions.answerD: The tractor and trailer can still be used together.
questions.explanation: A vehicle being equipped with anti-lock brakes on only the tractor or only the trailer provides additional control during braking.

questions.question: When traveling with cargo, the cargo should be checked:
questions.answerB: Before the trip and after the first 50 miles.
questions.answerD: Only after arriving to the final destination.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: When looking under your vehicle's hood during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the parking brakes and/or chock blocks.
questions.answerB: Leave the vehicle in a low gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting under a vehicle's hood, make sure the parking brake is engaged and/or the wheels are properly chocked.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerB: Exposure to moisture.
questions.explanation: If brakes are used too much, they will overheat and become less effective. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle loses its ABS?
questions.answerB: Pump the brake repeatedly.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: If carrying a heavy load that is slowing you down, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive in the right lane.
questions.answerD: Keep the vehicle in second gear.
questions.explanation: The right lanes of a roadway are generally intended for vehicles traveling more slowly than surrounding traffic. If being slowed down by a heavy load, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: If you see lights ahead while driving in fog:
questions.answerA: You can assume the lights are on the road.
questions.answerB: It may be a reflection.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.answerD: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: Test the low pressure warning signal:
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light function properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: How much water must be present for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A significant amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is a phenomenon during which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the road surface and begin to glide along on water on the road. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: A header board is used to:
questions.answerA: Allow a driver to see behind them.
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from moving cargo.
questions.answerD: Prevent the driver from leaving the tractor.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect drivers from moving cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.answerB: Glued down.
questions.explanation: Cargo on flatbed trailers or trailers without sides must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling in transit.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop your own route to show off your driving skills.
questions.answerB: Listen to directions from the examiner.
questions.answerC: Bring a passenger to ride with you.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must listen to and follow the directions given by the examiner. They will never ask you to drive in an unsafe manner.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerB: Exposure to moisture.
questions.explanation: If brakes are used too much, they will overheat and become less effective. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to stay awake on long trips.
questions.answerB: Is distracting.
questions.answerD: Should be used to prevent rust from forming.
questions.explanation: Always accelerate smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph, your vehicle's braking distance will become ____ times longer.
questions.answerB: Three
questions.explanation: If you double your speed, your braking distance will become four times longer. Similarly, the impact your vehicle would have in the case of a collision will also multiply by four.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to remove the vehicle from the tracks.
questions.answerD: Walk down the tracks to look for an oncoming train.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: If feeling tired and frequently yawning, you should:
questions.answerB: Get some coffee.
questions.answerD: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.explanation: Frequent yawning is a warning sign of fatigue. If you become tired while driving, the only safe response is to stop and get some sleep. You cannot rely on artificial stimulants, like caffeine, to keep you alert because they will eventually wear off and leave you more tired than you originally were.

questions.question: How can a person check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times and hold the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake makes a squeak, there may be a problem.
questions.answerD: Remove the rear wheel and listen for a noise when the brake pedal is depressed.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Damage to a suspension system can be very dangerous.

questions.question: When driving a 50-foot truck at 50 mph, you should maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.answerB: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: When traveling at speeds below 40 mph, you should maintain at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. At higher speeds, add an additional second.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerB: The vehicle touching an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerC: A driver properly completing an exercise in the skills test.
questions.answerD: An applicant trying to bribe the examiner.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection is required:
questions.answerB: To get fuel.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require that CMV drivers inspect their vehicles before every trip.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles require ____ to change gears.
questions.answerB: Double shifting
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears. A driver should release the accelerator, push in the clutch, and shift into neutral at the same time. After releasing the clutch and allowing the vehicle to change to the necessary speed, the driver should push in the clutch, shift gears, then simultaneously release the clutch and accelerate.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when:
questions.answerB: Air pressure falls below 20 psi.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure drops to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: If someone pulls out in front of you and you cannot stop to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Just hit the other vehicle since it will be the other driver's fault.
questions.answerB: Swerve to avoid the other car.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle pulls out in front of you, it is appropriate to brake as long as there is room for your vehicle to stop while you are using the appropriate braking technique. However, if you do not have room to stop, swerving may be a safer response.

questions.question: After starting a trip while transporting cargo:
questions.answerA: You will not need to inspect the cargo.
questions.answerB: The cargo should only be inspected if it is making noise.
questions.answerC: The cargo should only be inspected if there is an obvious concern.
questions.answerD: The cargo should be inspected after 50 miles on the road to ensure it is still properly secured.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: When entering a foggy area, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop on the side of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Pass other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Always slow down before entering a foggy area. Use low beam headlights, avoid passing others, and avoid stopping on the side of the roadway. It is safest to completely avoid driving under foggy conditions, if possible.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged at all speeds.
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When encountering fog, you will be safest if you:
questions.answerB: Don’t drive in the fog.
questions.answerD: Follow the vehicle ahead of you closely.
questions.explanation: Fog can quickly deteriorate drivers' ability to see the road, other drivers, and other hazards. Avoid driving in fog if at all possible.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.answerB: Tight.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: What can happen if parking brakes are used in very wet weather with temperatures below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.answerD: The brakes may become too smooth to be used.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should not be used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing. The brakes could become frozen in place, making it impossible to move the vehicle.

questions.question: If coolant has to be added to a system without a recovery tank, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the vehicle running while adding coolant.
questions.answerB: Open the radiator cap quickly.
questions.answerC: Not use gloves to touch the radiator cap.
questions.answerD: Wait for the engine to cool before adding coolant.
questions.explanation: Before adding coolant to a system without a recovery or overflow tank, you must turn the engine off and wait until it cools. Use gloves or a thick cloth to protect your hands. To release the pressure seal, turn the radiator cap slowly to the first stop.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The coolant level in the radiator.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine compartment, be sure to check the oil level; the radiator coolant level and the condition of the hoses; the power steering fluid level and the condition of the hoses, if applicable; the windshield washer fluid level; the battery connections, fluid level, and tie-downs; the automatic transmission fluid level; and the condition and tightness of the belts. Additionally, check for any leaks in the engine compartment and cracked or worn electrical wiring insulation.
