questions.explanation: Air brake system tanks must contain drain valves. These valves are used to drain accumulated oil and water from the tanks and may be either manually or automatically operated.

questions.question: When covering cargo, a cover that flaps in transit:
questions.answerB: Allows air to get to the cargo to keep it cool.
questions.explanation: If cargo is covered, the cover should not flap in the wind in transit. The cover could tear loose, uncovering the cargo while potentially blocking your view or the view of others.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place an appropriate amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about how the weight is distributed.
questions.answerD: Only place weight over the axles.
questions.explanation: The weight of cargo in a trailer should be evenly balanced. Having too much or too little weight on an axle can interfere with proper control of the vehicle. Additionally, having too much weight on one axle can damage it.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 8 psi in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The packages should be carried in the cab.
questions.answerC: The packages should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation surrounds packages of radioactive materials and passes through to other nearby packages. To address this, the number of radioactive packages that can be loaded together is limited.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: If stopped on the side of the road, how should you alert other motorists?
questions.answerB: Sound your horn.
questions.answerD: Keep the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important to turn on your four-way emergency flashers to warn other road users.

questions.question: If something is found to be unsafe during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue with the trip and make an appointment with a mechanic after the trip is completed.
questions.answerB: Let a more experienced driver use the truck.
questions.answerD: Not use the items found to be unsafe, but may continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals anything unsafe about your vehicle, you must get it repaired. It is illegal to operate an unsafe vehicle.

questions.question: Hydroplaning usually occurs:
questions.answerB: At speeds under 15 mph.
questions.answerC: In areas where water collects on the road.
questions.explanation: In places where water collects on the road, it is possible for a vehicle to hydroplane. Low tire pressure or worn tire tread makes this more likely to happen. If there is enough water on a road surface, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Should take over-the-counter remedies to wake them up.
questions.answerC: May make critical decisions too slowly.
questions.answerD: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: If you are fatigued, you will not see or react to hazards as quickly as you would if you were fully energized and awake. You will be impaired in making critical decisions.

questions.question: When checking the exhaust system, it should be:
questions.answerB: Leaking.
questions.explanation: When checking the exhaust system, you should verify that no parts of the system are loose, broken, or missing.

questions.question: When approaching an active railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear any approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train as it approaches.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of the train's horn.
questions.answerD: There will always be flashing warning lights.
questions.explanation: At a railroad crossing, do not assume that you will hear an approaching train. Trains may be prohibited from sounding their horns in certain areas, or the sound of its horn may be covered by noise from your vehicle. Do not assume that warning lights or other signals will announce a train.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Kept on the driver’s seat.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: What happens if brakes become too hot?
questions.answerB: They will harden.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick in to cool the brakes
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they may overheat and stop working. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table contains:
questions.answerB: Where the materials originated.
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: How much water needs to be on the surface of a road for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: A header board is used to:
questions.answerA: Allow a driver to see behind them.
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from moving cargo.
questions.answerD: Prevent the driver from leaving the tractor.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect drivers from moving cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, what should you do when the engine is close to idle?
questions.answerB: Push out the clutch.
questions.explanation: When stopping a vehicle with a manual transmission, you should push in the clutch when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerB: Honking your horn.
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Brace containers so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation. All hazardous materials packages must be secured.

questions.question: How can a person check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times and hold the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake makes a squeak, there may be a problem.
questions.answerD: Remove the rear wheel and listen for a noise when the brake pedal is depressed.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: Turn on their emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important that you turn on your emergency flashers as a warning to other drivers. This is especially important if you are stopped at night.

questions.question: A skid caused by acceleration can likely be solved by:
questions.answerA: Removing your foot from the accelerator.
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.explanation: Skids caused by acceleration frequently occur on slippery road surfaces. These skids can generally be resolved by the driver removing their foot from the accelerator.

questions.question: On a wet road, you should reduce your speed:
questions.answerB: By about one-third.
questions.explanation: You should reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: What is a wig wag?
questions.answerB: A tube used to move air from the compressor to the tanks
questions.answerC: A noise made by air brakes when used
questions.answerD: A part within the braking unit that allows air to move freely
questions.explanation: A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device in an air brake system. It drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view when the air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.answerB: Hoses.
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerB: Exposure to moisture.
questions.explanation: If brakes are used too much, they will overheat and become less effective. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: Fueling with passengers on board:
questions.answerB: Should only be done if absolutely necessary.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern as long as the passengers stay inside the bus.
questions.answerD: Should be done to show the passengers that there is enough fuel to get to the next stop.
questions.explanation: You should not refuel a bus while passengers are on board, unless it is absolutely necessary to do so. In particular, never refuel a bus carrying passengers while inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerB: Have an emergency plan.
questions.answerD: Drive faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: Where can you find the tire load rating?
questions.answerA: On the inside of the driver’s door
questions.answerB: On the dashboard
questions.answerC: On the side of each tire
questions.explanation: A tire load rating is the maximum safe weight that can be carried by a tire at a specified pressure. This number is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerA: At a rate that changes depending on how much alcohol is in the body.
questions.answerB: At a consistent rate, regardless of how much alcohol is in the body.
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person drinks coffee.
questions.answerD: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate that cannot be accelerated through common tricks, such as drinking coffee or taking a cold shower. The only way to sober up after drinking is to give your body the time it requires to process the alcohol out of your system.

questions.question: If a truck's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working:
questions.answerA: The truck will not have any brakes.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven only at slow speeds.
questions.answerC: The truck will still have brakes.
questions.answerD: The truck will lack brakes on its left side.
questions.explanation: If an ABS system fails, the vehicle will still have normal braking function. The driver should continue to drive and brake as they normally would.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerB: Have an emergency plan.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerB: Honking your horn.
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: Tread depth in the major grooves on a front tire should be at least:
questions.answerB: 2/32 of an inch.
questions.explanation: Tires need to have at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on other tires.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.answerB: Axle.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: Before driving a bus, you must:
questions.answerA: Review its most recent inspection report.
questions.answerB: Wash the outside.
questions.explanation: A bus must always be inspected before it is driven. The inspection process must include a review of the inspection report made by the previous driver. You should operate the vehicle only if defects listed on the inspection report have been certified as repaired or as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerB: One-eighth of a second
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 6 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Baggage and freight should be stored in a way that:
questions.answerA: Allows riders to exit by any door or window in an emergency.
questions.answerB: Blocks an exit, if at least one other exit is available to passengers.
questions.answerC: Partially covers a door, since the items can be moved aside.
questions.answerD: Allows the cargo to be easily offloaded in an emergency.
questions.explanation: On a bus, all baggage and freight should be stored in a manner that allows the driver to move freely and easily; allows riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency; and protects riders from injury if items fall or shift.

questions.question: In a convex mirror, objects seem ____ than they actually are.
questions.answerB: Smaller
questions.explanation: A convex mirror makes objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: In an engine compartment, loose belts will:
questions.answerA: Not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, causing the engine to overheat.
questions.answerB: Make the engine run more efficiently.
questions.answerC: Make the fan run too much, causing the engine to run too coolly.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check the tightness of the belts in your engine compartment. Loose belts will not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, which can lead the engine overheating.

questions.question: When stopping at a railroad crossing, opening the forward door:
questions.answerA: Can increase your chances of hearing an approaching train.
questions.answerB: Should never be done.
questions.answerC: Could allow other noises to enter the bus, making it more difficult to hear any approaching trains.
questions.answerD: Will take too long and is discouraged.
questions.explanation: When stopping a bus at a railroad crossing, you should open your forward door if doing so will improve your ability to see or hear an approaching train.

questions.question: What is Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The loaded weight of a single vehicle as stated by the manufacturer
questions.answerB: The total weight of the vehicle without a laod
questions.answerC: The total weight of the cargo minus the containers used to transport the load
questions.answerD: The maximum weight allowed to be transported by a vehicle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Obey all traffic laws.
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: How should you check your hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly move toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.answerD: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should be easy to push to the floor.
questions.explanation: To test hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: Stay in the driver's lane.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing for you to do is get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact, do not challenge them by increasing your speed, and do not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they direct toward you.

questions.question: When you double your speed from 20 to 40 mph, your vehicle's braking distance will become ____ times longer.
questions.answerB: Three
questions.explanation: If you double your speed, your braking distance will become four times longer. Similarly, the impact your vehicle would have in the case of a collision will also multiply by four.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerB: Temperature.
questions.explanation: Stopping distance is affected by a vehicle's speed. The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become.

questions.question: What can happen if one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected?
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.answerD: The driver will be asked to decrease the weight of the load.
questions.explanation: If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: Regardless the size of the cargo, it should be secured by at least ____ tie-down(s).
questions.answerB: Two
questions.explanation: Cargo that is required to be tied down should be secured by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo length. However, at least two tie-downs should be used no matter how small the cargo is.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.answerB: It increases slightly.
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will multiply its braking distance by four.

questions.question: Front wheel braking works:
questions.answerB: Under all conditions.
questions.answerC: Only if the road is dry.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: If you see lights ahead while driving in fog:
questions.answerA: You can assume the lights are on the road.
questions.answerB: It may be a reflection.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.answerD: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Are not controlled by any type of traffic control device.
questions.answerC: Have gates that lower when trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Should never be crossed by a CMV.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that are not controlled by any type of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: What is Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW)?
questions.answerA: The total weight of a vehicle and its cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a vehicle before cargo
questions.answerD: The maximum weight allowed to be transported by a vehicle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of a single vehicle and its load of cargo.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerB: But only in hot weather.
questions.answerD: While minimizing the vehicle's fuel use.
questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: When checking the air and electrical lines during a vehicle inspection, all of the following should be true, except:
questions.answerA: The air hoses are making a hissing noise.
questions.answerB: The air hoses and electrical lines are not cut.
questions.answerC: The air lines are not pinched.
questions.answerD: The air lines are not dragging against tractor parts.
questions.explanation: When examining the air and electrical lines as part of your vehicle inspection test, you must listen for leaks. Ensure that the air hoses and electrical lines are not cut, chafed, spliced, or worn. Make sure air and electrical lines are not tangled, pinched, or dragging against tractor parts.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Have air pressure in the braking system even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking system when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build air pressure to allow the brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Maintain air pressure when shut off for periods of less than four hours.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.answerB: Axle.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.answerB: One quarter
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only occur if there is enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can brake 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should continue driving, but turn the emergency flashers on to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning light turns on, you should stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. Controlled braking will be possible only as long as enough air remains in the tanks.

questions.question: The air entering air storage tanks may contain:
questions.answerB: Frost.
questions.explanation: The air that enters air storage tanks in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. Because accumulations of these materials can damage the braking system, tanks are equipped with drains to allow their removal.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerB: 50 psi
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: If one air system in a dual air brake system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully.
questions.answerC: There will be no noticeable affect.
questions.answerD: Lights on the outside of the tractor will flash.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: At what psi is the safety valve set to open?
questions.answerB: 150 psi
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the first tank that receives compressed air has a safety valve that releases air if the pressure gets too high. It is usually set to open at 150 psi. If the valve must open, there is a fault in the system that should be repaired by a mechanic.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive with one foot on the accelerator and one foot on the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signals activate, it is essential that you bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle using air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal toward them.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in an air-braked vehicle, push the brake pedal down and control the pressure so that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerB: Only required when transporting liquids.
questions.answerC: Required when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: With some exceptions, you must have a tank endorsement to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous substances.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.answerB: Hoses.
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.answerD: Will also affect the other system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Air compressor governor
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: Where is the safety relief valve usually located?
questions.answerB: Near the front brake
questions.explanation: An air brake system's safety relief valve is located in the tank that is first to receive air from the compressor.

questions.question: What should happen if the air pressure in the air brake system tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light should come on.
questions.answerB: Lights should flash on the outside of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A message should appear on the control panel.
questions.explanation: On vehicles with air brakes, a low air pressure warning signal will come on if the pressure in the air tanks falls below 60 psi. On large buses, the signal may activate at 80 to 85 psi.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Cannot be used with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Should be used on dry pavement.
questions.answerC: Can assist in maintaining control when braking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used if all axles have ABS.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air braking systems. ABS helps maintain control of a vehicle and prevents the wheels from locking up during hard braking on slippery surfaces. ABS can still provide benefits even if is present on only one axle.

questions.question: If a vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. In what condition should the belt be?
questions.answerB: Tight
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with air brakes that has a belt-driven air compressor, you should check the condition and tightness of the belt. It should be in good condition.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerB: Exposure to moisture.
questions.explanation: If brakes are used too much, they will overheat and become less effective. This is referred to as brake fade.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerB: Dual air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual system has two separate air brake systems with a single set of controls.

questions.question: To inspect slack adjusters on S-cam brakes, you need to:
questions.answerA: Park on a hill and test the brakes.
questions.answerB: Put on gloves and push in the slack adjusters.
questions.answerC: Remove the drum and look inside.
questions.answerD: Chock the wheels and disengage the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.answerB: The parking brake system
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: What can happen if parking brakes are used in very wet weather with temperatures below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.answerD: The brakes may become too smooth to be used.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should not be used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing. The brakes could become frozen in place, making it impossible to move the vehicle.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.answerB: Four tanks
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter air tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from air tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks are equipped with drains that allow water and compressor oil to be removed from the system. If allowed to build up, water and compressor oil can damage an air brake system.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.answerD: Will also affect the other system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.answerB: Brakes overheat.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.answerB: Axle.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Air compressor governor
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.answerB: Dual
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: Air brakes are:
questions.answerA: An effective tool for stopping large vehicles.
questions.answerB: Prohibited on large vehicles.
questions.answerD: A tool to improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: As long as the brakes are properly maintained, using air brakes is a safe and effective method of stopping large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Cannot be used with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Should be used on dry pavement.
questions.answerC: Can assist in maintaining control when braking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used if all axles have ABS.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air braking systems. ABS helps maintain control of a vehicle and prevents the wheels from locking up during hard braking on slippery surfaces. ABS can still provide benefits even if is present on only one axle.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle using air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal toward them.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in an air-braked vehicle, push the brake pedal down and control the pressure so that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.answerB: C-cam drum brake.
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: If a vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. In what condition should the belt be?
questions.answerB: Tight
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with air brakes that has a belt-driven air compressor, you should check the condition and tightness of the belt. It should be in good condition.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.answerB: Voice-activated brakes.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Have air pressure in the braking system even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking system when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build air pressure to allow the brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Maintain air pressure when shut off for periods of less than four hours.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, what happens if one system is low on pressure?
questions.answerA: The air from the other system will be used to supplement the system with the low pressure.
questions.answerB: The front or rear brakes may not work properly.
questions.answerD: The low system will use an auxiliary system to fill the tank.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerB: Only required when transporting liquids.
questions.answerC: Required when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: With some exceptions, you must have a tank endorsement to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous substances.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located ____ a brake drum.
questions.answerB: Inside
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.answerD: Clean the air in the passenger compartment.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes. Manually operated drains should be used daily.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerB: Open the hood.
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Place cargo high.
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: What is the Johnson bar?
questions.answerA: A hand valve that works the trailer brakes
questions.answerB: A valve that indicates the fuel level
questions.answerC: A valve that measures the amount of liquid in the air brake system
questions.answerD: A valve that allows for the release of excess pressure in the braking system
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: When driving a trailer with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Not depress the brakes as much as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerD: Try to not brakes as often as you would when driving a vehicle without ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if operating a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.answerB: When partially loaded.
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerA: Regularly to activate the trailer brakes in all driving conditions.
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Only in inclement weather when the trailer may skid.
questions.answerD: Only if the trailer is carrying a load.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should be used only to test the trailer brakes. It should not be used while driving because it may cause the trailer to skid.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.answerB: The trailer emergency brakes.
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Release the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: If a trailer is too high:
questions.answerA: It will not make a difference when coupling.
questions.answerB: It may not couple correctly.
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: ____ are the cause of more than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths.
questions.answerB: Motorcycles
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.

questions.question: If colors are being used to distinguish glad hands, which color is used for service lines?
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.explanation: When trailer air lines are color-coded, the service lines are generally blue and the emergency lines are generally red.

questions.question: Look for matching colors when coupling glad hands. Service lines are often:
questions.answerB: Orange.
questions.explanation: When coupling glad hands, make sure to couple together matching glad hands. To help drivers avoid mistakes, color coding is sometimes used. Service lines are often coded with the color blue and emergency lines are often coded with the color red.

questions.question: When a combination vehicle goes around a corner:
questions.answerA: The turn should be made as tightly as possible.
questions.answerB: The front and rear wheels move in different paths.
questions.answerC: The rear wheels should run over the curb.
questions.answerD: It is acceptable for street signs to be knocked over if they are too close to the road.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. This effect is especially pronounced on vehicles with trailers.

questions.question: Trailers manufactured after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Proper coupling technique:
questions.answerA: Is the same on all vehicles.
questions.answerB: Is essential to the safe operation of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Includes ensuring that the fifth wheel plate is not greased.
questions.explanation: Knowing proper coupling and uncoupling technique is fundamental to the safe operation of combination vehicles. Improper coupling can be very dangerous.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerD: To test the lights on the trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerA: Does not change braking in any way.
questions.answerB: Is not possible.
questions.answerC: Will allow the driver additional control over their vehicle when braking.
questions.answerD: Will cause extra strain on the other axles.
questions.explanation: Having an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) on only the trailer, or even on just one axle, will still provide a driver with additional control over the trailer when braking.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should not:
questions.answerB: Apply the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerC: Allow the wheels to grip the road.
questions.answerD: Allow the trailer to straighten out.
questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake to attempt to straighten out the rig because it will only prolong the skid. The application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: Starting in which year were newly manufactured trailers required to have ABS?
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: A lightly-loaded combination vehicle will stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have high traction.
questions.answerB: The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have low traction.
questions.answerC: The brakes only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs only operate when a trailer reaches a minimum weight.
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. The stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction on a light trailer than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when drivers:
questions.answerB: Do not driving fast enough.
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver taking a turn at too high a speed. Be sure to take turns and curves safely and slowly.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerB: Have reduced braking capabilities.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand valve while driving:
questions.answerB: Will stop your trailer safely.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.answerB: May feel squishy.
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.answerB: Exchange line
questions.explanation: The service line, also called the control line or signal line, carries air to the trailer brakes and is controlled by the foot brake or trailer hand brake.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.answerB: When partially loaded.
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: Avoid needing to make sudden lane changes by:
questions.answerA: Using your horn to encourage other drivers to move out of your lane.
questions.answerB: Only driving slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Watching the road ahead while driving.
questions.answerD: Pulling off the road and waiting when there is high traffic.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous when driving a combination vehicle. Avoid the need to make a sudden lane change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Are usually shorter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerD: Are easier to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single commercial vehicles. For these reasons, they usually require more driving skill than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerB: Requires more driving skill
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed near the front of a trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed near the rear of a trailer.
questions.answerD: Loaded with most weight on the driver’s side of a trailer.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of rollover, the weight of cargo in a trailer should be centered and spread out as much as possible. The weight of the cargo should also be kept as low to the ground as possible.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerB: You are stopped.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen as a result of drivers taking turns too fast.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.answerB: Supply line.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: Rollovers are most likely to happen when:
questions.answerB: Driver turn too slowly.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when an operator turns too fast. Drivers should be sure to slow down before entering turns and curves, especially when transporting a fully-loaded rig.

questions.question: ____ are the cause of more than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths.
questions.answerB: Motorcycles
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.
